title: A new onboarding experience on Mastodon

last_post.content:
Easy to miss in Mastodon's latest update, but the most-requested features are indeed coming "soon:"

"...quote posts, improved content and profile search, and groups. We’re also continuously working on improving content and profile discovery, onboarding, and of course our extensive set of moderation tools, as well as removing friction from decentralized features. Keep a lookout for these updates soon."

https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2023/05/a-new-onboarding-experience-on-mastodon/

WebGPU, the new graphics API for JavaScript, shipped in a stable web browser (Chrome 113) about… an hour ago!

I have written a blog post about it, covering a brief (okay, not brief) history of graphics APIs to ~situate WebGPU in a context~, a brief general guide to writing WebGPU, and some specific resources for making WebGPU projects in TypeScript, Rust, and C++ (you can use it on desktop! it doesn't have to be in a browser).

I think WebGPU is really good.

https://cohost.org/mcc/post/1406157-i-want-to-talk-about-webgpu

title: Just Because ChatBots Can’t Think Doesn’t Mean They Can’t Lie

last_post.content:
Better people than me might be able to suppress a chuckle upon discovering that on the very same blog, Professor Cowen recently argued that Francis Bacon was a vehement opponent of the printing press — based on quotations that Bacon never wrote and which appear to have been generated by ChatGPT.

I don't know his GRE scores so I can't comment on their external validity, but given what I do know I can assure you that he's overpaid.

https://www.thenation.com/article/culture/internet-archive-publishers-lawsuit-chatbot/

title: Are Emergent Abilities of Large Language Models a Mirage?

last_post.content:
#LLMs #NewPreprintThread #neuroscience @cogsci @philosophy

1/n

Really interesting new preprint on emergence in LLMs. It raises a whole number of interesting issues, so some initial, first thoughts in the hope of prompting more discussion.

I also suspect this paper will generate a fair bit of confusion due to the central notion of 'emergence'

First off, the paper is looking at the issue of *how model capabilities develop as a function of model size.*

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.15004

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

I have remade my open textbook 'Improving Your Statistical Inferences' in Quarto. https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/ All 'Test Yourself' questions at the bottom of each chapter are now interactive thanks to the 'webexercises' package (thanks @debruine and @dalejbarr !). Someone recently called my material 'thoughtful frequentist statistics'. I think that is a very nice summary.

THE 90-90 RULE OF SOFTWARE

The first 90% of the code accounts for the first 90% of the development time.

The remaining 10% of the code accounts for the other 90% of the development time.

Again, I have to re-iterate this: https://calckey.social registrations are closed today.

Nor am I giving away invitation codes.

I know there's lots of demand, but we've been crushed by an on rush of registration requests over the past few days -- and we need to ensure a better experience for current https://calckey.social users.

New blog post looking at #RStats package developer statistics on CRAN: https://tidytales.ca/posts/2023-05-03_r-developers/

I take a stab at answering questions like:

- How many R developers are there?
- How many packages have they contributed to?
- What were their roles?

There’s also an interactive {gt} table in the post, so you can look at your own stats if you have authorship on any CRAN packages, or see who the most prolific authors are.

title: Strange but true: the expanding Universe doesn't conserve energy

last_post.content:
RT @StartsWithABang
Strange but true: the expanding Universe doesn't conserve energy

The conservation of energy is one of the most important laws in all of physics, applying to all forces and lab experiments.

But for the overall Universe, that's no longer true.

Here's why.
https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/expanding-universe-conserve-energy/

title: Movie Licensing USA: Public Libraries | Swank Motion Pictures

last_post.content:
My library is showing A Wrinkle In Time as a good movie book tie-in for their youth programming. It's going to be fun! However, this is how we have to advertise it (with no title) because of idiotic copyright laws and licensing agreements.

This is not to say that all copyright is idiotic (though some of it is), but that public library movie licensing is dumb. We get a blanket license from the State of Vermont through SWANK. Details here.

https://www.swank.com/public-libraries/customer-hub/

This is how the FBI unmasked the person behind a service that allowed criminals to check whether a credit card was valid and active.

It took them 10 years and undercover work that revealed the service was processing millions of credit card numbers.

One of the keys in the investigation was that the suspect, named Denis Kulkov, stored evidence of his crimes in his email account.

https://techcrunch.com/2023/05/04/try2check-credit-card-fraudster/
